newsitem.title: USA: US stocks hold steady despite skidding bonds.
newsitem.headline: US stocks hold steady despite skidding bonds.

text.p: U.S. stocks held steady despite stiff selling in the bond market, as investors renewed their bargain-hunting in laggard issues and focused attention on smaller cap issues.

The steadiness in stocks amid the bond selloff "is somewhat surprising," said Ed Nicoski, a Piper Jaffray technical analyst. "What we've seen the last few weeks and very noticeably yesterday is smaller caps acting better than blue chips. The Russell 200 is up and the S&P is down. There's bargain-hunting in depressed issues and that will probably help preclude a major selloff in the near-term."
The Dow industrials rose 11 to 6434. The S&P 500 was off fractionally to 745. The Russell 2000, a measure of small company stocks, rose one to 359.
The Nasdaq Composite rose four to 1301.
Losers outpaced winners 12-11 on heavy NYSE volume of 347 million shares.
The long bond slumped 1-11/32 to yield 6.50 percent amid profit-taking and technical selling and some wariness ahead of Friday's key November employment report.
